prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity needed: We expect that the typical intensity of the 12CO(2-1) line is 10K or stronger with a velocity line width of a few km/s inferred from the Galactic GMC observations. In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.3 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. From previous ALMA observations of N159W (see Scientific Justification), we expect to detect molecular lines of 13CO (2-1), C18O(2-1) toward the dense clumps with this sensitivity.
Angular resolution We would like to resolve high-density cores spatially because the size and the mass distributions are the key for this study. We then choose an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.36pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.
Areas to be covered Mosaic region is selected from a comparisons of high resolution data in mm and submm with infrared data to select a quiescent molecular clumps. The region will be also covered in CO isotopes, CS and H alpha in Band 3 in Cycle 1 but with slightly lower resolution of 3 arcsec (0.7pc)

Sensitivity needed: We expect that the typical intensity of the HCO line is about 1 K with a velocity line width of a few km/s inferred from the Galactic GMC observations and from previous Mopra and SEST observations of the LMC. In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.3 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s for Mosaic. With this sensitivity, we expect to detect molecular lines of other high density tracers as well as H alpha emission toward the dense clumps.
Angular resolution We would like to resolve high-density cores spatially because the size and the mass distributions are the key for this study. We then choose an angular resolution of 2 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.5pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.
Areas to be covered Mosaic region is selected from a comparisons of high resolution data in mm and submm with infrared data to select a quiescent molecular clumps. Because we expect to have extended emissions across the cloud, we need ACA observations. The region will be also covered in CO isotopes, CS and H alpha in Band 3 in Cycle 1 but with slightly lower resolution of 3 arcsec (0.7pc)

The region will be also covered in CO isotopes, CS and H alpha in Band 3 in Cycle 1 but with slightly lower resolution of 3 arcsec (0.7pc)

In this study, both the spatial and velocity information is important to investigate the dynamics, and then we adopt the desired sensitivity as 0.3 K (rms) with a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s for Mosaic. With this sensitivity, we expect to detect molecular lines of other high density tracers as well as H alpha emission toward the dense clumps.

We then choose an angular resolution of 2 arcsec, which corresponds to a size scale of 0.5pc. The molecular gas is expected to be spatially extended in the primary beam, and then the ACA (7m+TP) will be definitely needed.
Areas to be covered Mosaic region is selected from a comparisons of high resolution data in mm and submm with infrared data to select a quiescent molecular clumps. Because we expect to have extended emissions across the cloud, we need ACA observations. The region will be also covered in CO isotopes, CS and H alpha in Band 3 in Cycle 1 but with slightly lower resolution of 3 arcsec (0.7pc)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Large Magellanic Cloud is the nearest neighbor to the Galaxy, and its nearly face-on view allows us to unambiguously identify young objects associated with GMCs over a galaxy. We classified the GMCs into three types according to the activities of massive star formation, corresponding to the evolutional sequence of the GMCs. One of the features of the GMCs in the LMC is that there are many starless GMCs, suggesting that the timescale in star formation is significantly longer than in the Galaxy. This may be due to the higher ionization degree and smaller cooling rate as a consequence of lower metallicity in the LMC, and it is tempting to speculate that there is a link between populous clusters and the starless GMCs. Our Cycle 1 approved program will map 5 GMCs of different GMC types to resolve molecular cloud cores at sub-parsec scales in CO. Here we propose to follow-up on the two youngest GMCs, G225 and N166, to probe the high-density clump mass structure and to characterize precluster forming cores, which leads to the understanding of the possible origin of high activities of star and cluster formation in the LMC.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00603.S, "Tracing evolution of giant molecular clouds in the Large Magellanic Cloud", Akiko Kawamura

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
